reagents_conditions: Gaseous X₂ in the presence of UV light
observation:
1. X = Cl: Yellow Cl₂ decolourises.
2. X = Br: Reddish-brown Br₂ decolourises.
additional_information:
X-X bond undergoes homolytic fission to produce X* as free radical.
This reaction consists of 3 stages: Initiation, propagation, and termination.
If X₂ is in excess, the reaction will result in polysubstituted compounds.

H-X bond undergoes heterolytic fission to produce H⁺ to act as electrophile
to attack the electron-rich C=C bond.
Note that if the alkene is unsymmetrical, this reaction follow Markovnikov's rule, by
which the major product is formed from the most stable carbocation.

observation: When X = Br: Orange-red (organic solvent)/Orange (aq) Br₂ decolourises.
additional_information:
When X₂ molecule approaches the electron-rich C=C bond, the X atom closer to the
C=C bond has an induced ƍ+ charge, while the other X atom has an induced ƍ- charge.
Hence, X-X bond undergoes heterolytic fission to produce X⁺ to act as electrophile
to attack the electron-rich C=C bond.

reagents_conditions: (1) Cold, concentrated H₂SO₄ and (2) Water, heat
additional_information:
The O-H bond undergoes heterolytic fission to give H+ to act as an electrophile
to attack the electron-rich C=C bond.

observation:
1. Alkaline medium: Purple KMnO₄ decolourises, brown precipitate of MnO₂ is formed.
2. Acidic medium: Purple KMnO₄ decolourises.
additional_information: This reaction is also called oxidative addition or mild oxidation.

This reaction is called oxidative cleavage. The reaction here gives one of the possible products,
carbon dioxide and water. These products are formed if the C= atom has no alkyl group attached.

This reaction is called oxidative cleavage. The reaction here gives one of the possible products,
carboxylic acid. These products are formed if the C= atom has 1 alkyl group attached.

This reaction is called oxidative cleavage. The reaction here gives one of the possible products,
ketone. These products are formed if the C= atom has 2 alkyl groups attached.

reagents_conditions: X₂ in the absence of UV light, anhyrdrous AlX₃
observation:
1. X = Cl: Yellow Cl₂ decolourises.
2. X = Br: Reddish-brown Br₂ decolourises.
additional_information:
One of the X atoms donates a pair of electrons to AlX₃, forming X⁺ to act as the electrophile: X₂ + AlX₃ → AlX₄⁻ + X⁺
2 π electrons of the benzene are attracted towards the electrophile, forming a short-lived carbocation intermediate. The unstable carbocation loses
a H⁺ to restore the resonance structure of benzene, the H⁺ reacts with AlX₄⁻ to regenerate the catalyst and HX.

The X atom of RX donates a pair of electrons to AlX₃, forming R⁺ to act as the electrophile: X₂ + AlX₃ → AlX₄⁻ + X⁺
2 π electrons of the benzene are attracted towards the electrophile, forming a short-lived carbocation intermediate. The unstable carbocation loses
a H⁺ to restore the resonance structure of benzene, the H⁺ reacts with AlX₄⁻ to regenerate the catalyst and HX.

NO₂⁺ is generated via: HNO₃ + H₂SO₄ → NO₂⁺ + HSO₄⁻ + H₂O
2 π electrons of the benzene are attracted towards the electrophile, forming a short-lived carbocation intermediate. The unstable carbocation loses
a H⁺ to restore the resonance structure of benzene, the H⁺ reacts with HSO₄⁻ to regenerate the catalyst.
